**Scott Derrickson** (born July 16, 1966) is an American filmmaker. He is known for his work in the horror genre, directing films such as _[The Exorcism of Emily Rose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Exorcism_of_Emily_Rose)_ (2005), _[Sinister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinister_(film))_ (2012), and _[The Black Phone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Black_Phone)_ (2021). He is also known for the superhero film _[Doctor Strange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Strange_(2016_film))_ (2016), based on the [Marvel Comics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Comics) character.

## Early life

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scott_Derrickson&action=edit&section=1)\]

Scott Derrickson grew up in [Denver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver), Colorado. He graduated from [Biola University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biola_University) with a [BA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts) in [Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanities) with an emphasis in philosophy and literature and a B.A. in [communications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications) with an emphasis in film and a minor in theology.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Biola-1) He completed his graduate studies at [USC School of Cinema-Television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USC_School_of_Cinema-Television).

## Career

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scott_Derrickson&action=edit&section=2)\]

Derrickson's debut feature was _[Hellraiser: Inferno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellraiser:_Inferno)_, the fifth installment in the [long-running _Hellraiser_ film series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellraiser_(film_series)). It was released [straight to video](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straight_to_video) in 2000. Following this, Derrickson and co-writer [Paul Harris Boardman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Harris_Boardman) spent several years doing [script-doctoring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Script_doctor) work for studios. "I was paid to write or rewrite 13 screenplays," Derrickson said, "None of them got made. I was earning a good living but all of my creativity would be read by just a handful of executives. It caused a kind of soul sickness in me."[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-3) Some of Derrickson and Boardman's unproduced scripts include _[Future Tense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Future_Tense)_, _[The Mystic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#The_Mystic)_, _[Ghosting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Ghosting)_ and _[Mindbender](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Mindbender)_.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-4)

Derrickson co-wrote and directed _[The Exorcism of Emily Rose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Exorcism_of_Emily_Rose)_, which was loosely based on a true story about [Anneliese Michel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anneliese_Michel).[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-washingtonpost-5) The film was named in the Chicago Film Critics Association's list of the "Top 100 Scariest Films Ever Made." Theatrical box office gross for _The Exorcism of Emily Rose_ was over $144 million worldwide.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-BOM-6) It received the award for Best Horror Film at the [32nd Saturn Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/32nd_Saturn_Awards).

Derrickson with star [Keanu Reeves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keanu_Reeves) in 2008

**Edward Davis Wood Jr.** (October 10, 1924 – December 10, 1978) was an American filmmaker, actor, screenwriter, and pulp novelist.

In the 1950s, Wood directed several [low-budget](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B_movie) science fiction, crime and horror films that later became [cult classics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cult_classics), notably _[Glen or Glenda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glen_or_Glenda)_ (1953), _[Jail Bait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jail_Bait_(1954_film))_ (1954), _[Bride of the Monster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bride_of_the_Monster)_ (1955), _[Plan 9 from Outer Space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_9_from_Outer_Space)_ (1957) and _[Night of the Ghouls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_of_the_Ghouls)_ (1959).[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood#cite_note-Rudolph_Grey_1992_pg._197-1) In the 1960s and 1970s, he moved towards [sexploitation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexploitation_film) and [pornographic films](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pornographic_film) such as _[The Sinister Urge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sinister_Urge_(film))_ (1960), _[Orgy of the Dead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orgy_of_the_Dead)_ (1965) and _[Necromania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Necromania)_ (1971), and wrote over 80 lurid [pulp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulp_magazine) crime and sex novels.

Notable for their [campy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_(style)) aesthetics, technical errors, unsophisticated [special effects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_effects), use of poorly-matched [stock footage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_footage), eccentric casts, idiosyncratic stories and non sequitur dialogue, Wood's films remained largely obscure until he was posthumously awarded a [Golden Turkey Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Golden_Turkey_Awards) for Worst Director of All Time in 1980, renewing public interest in his life and work.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraig2009276-2)

Following the publication of [Rudolph Grey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Grey)'s 1992 oral biography _Nightmare of Ecstasy: The Life and Art of Edward D. Wood Jr._, a biopic of his life, _[Ed Wood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood_(film))_ (1994), was directed by [Tim Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Burton). Starring [Johnny Depp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnny_Depp) as Wood and [Martin Landau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Landau) as [Bela Lugosi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bela_Lugosi), the film received critical acclaim and various awards, including two [Academy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Awards).

## Early years\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ed_Wood&action=edit&section=1)\]

Wood's father, Edward Sr., worked for the [United States Post Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Post_Office) as a [custodian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janitor), and his family relocated numerous times around the United States. Eventually, they settled ...

_**Meet Corliss Archer**_ is an American radio program from [radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio)'s [Golden Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old-time_radio) that ran from January 7, 1943, to September 30, 1956. Although it was [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS)'s answer to [NBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC)'s _[A Date with Judy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Date_with_Judy)_, it was also broadcast by NBC in 1948 as a summer replacement for _[The Bob Hope Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Hope)_. From October 3, 1952, to June 26, 1953, it aired on [ABC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company), finally returning to CBS. Despite the program's long run, fewer than 24 episodes are known to exist.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

## Characters and story\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Meet_Corliss_Archer&action=edit&section=1)\]

Priscilla Lyon and [Janet Waldo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janet_Waldo) successively portrayed 15-year-old Corliss on radio. [Lugene Sanders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lugene_Sanders) also played Corliss briefly on radio[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer#cite_note-sies-1) and in the [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS) version of the _Meet Corliss Archer_ television show.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer#cite_note-etvs-2)

Perpetually perky, breathless and well-intentioned, Corliss is constantly at the side of her next-door neighbor and boyfriend, Dexter Franklin (Bill Christy, [Sam Edwards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Edwards)). Clumsy, nerdy Dexter, a sweet but constant bungler with a nasal voice, is best remembered for his trademark phrase, " [Holy cow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_cow_(expression))!" and his braying call, "Heyyyy, Corrrrrliiiiiss!"—...

Guldner) Kiss and Tell is a 1945 American comedy film starring then 17-year-old Shirley Temple as Corliss Archer. In the film, two teenage girls cause their respective parents much concern when they start to become interested in boys. The parents’ bickering about which girl is the worse influence causes more problems than it solves. The movie was based on the Broadway play Kiss and Tell, which was based on the Corliss Archer short stories. The stories, play and movie were all written by F. Hugh Herbert. A sequel film, A Kiss for Corliss, was released in 1949 and also starred Temple, but was not written by Herbert.

Title: Shirley Temple Black's Remarkable Second Act as a Diplomat by Claudia Kalb
URL: https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/shirley-temple-black-second-act-diplomat-180980038/
[Women Who Shaped History](https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/women-who-shaped-history-180968116/)

A _Smithsonian_ magazine special report

![a black and white photo of Shirley Temple Black speaking at a microphone](https://th-thumbnailer.cdn-si-edu.com/R8s9JIejVYRwuc8x4CXPLQ_mZpE=/1000x750/filters:no_upscale():focal(734x581:735x582)/https://tf-cmsv2-smithsonianmag-media.s3.amazonaws.com/filer_public/53/a6/53a61b4e-901f-4e56-b8ca-90d9a3bf2a06/jun2022_f04_prologue.jpg)In closing remarks at the 1969 U.N. General Assembly in New York, Black recalled an Apollo 12 astronaut who, while in orbit, remarked on the Earth’s beauty. “Some of us down here are not so sure,” she said.
FAMILY OF SHIRLEY TEMPLE BLACK

In June 1972, Shirley Temple Black took on one of the biggest roles of her life: United States delegate to the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment. The tap-dancing child actress with her golden ringlets and magnetic appeal was 44 years old and an unmistakable presence at the first international meeting to address the crisis of global pollution, held in Stockholm. “You could usually locate her by following the clicking of shutters and the popping of flash bulbs,” the _San Francisco Examiner_ reported. But Black’s value was more than mere fame. She had come to deliver an all-inclusive message, which even now, 50 years later, seems ahead of its time. People must unite with empathy and humility, she said, to restore the world for future generations: “We are trustees of the earth they will inherit.”

![Shirley Temple as child actor](https://th-thumbnailer.cdn-si-edu.com/9_A0yf41Koo7vF4T4ftSahfRpXM=/fit-in/1072x0/filters:focal(360x539:361x540)/https://tf-cmsv2-smithsonianmag-media.s3.amazonaws.com/filer_public/6b/bc/6bbc1d90-fe12-4da1-a88b-b8be16c23825/jun2022_f18_prologue.jpg)An 11-year-old Shirley Temple, in a 1939 promotional photograph for The Little Princess, her 26th full-length feature film.
ALAMY; ALAIN NOGUES

In the 1930s, Shirley Temple had served as America’s antidote to the Great Depression in such films as _The Little Colonel_ and _Bright Eyes_, appearing on-screen for the first time when she was just 3 years old. But her career as a child star was serendipitous—film producers had discovered her in a Los Angeles dance class—and she refused to let her early stardom define her as an adult. Instead, after marrying her second husband, Charles Black, an aquaculture engineer and oceanographer, and raising three children in the hills west of Palo Alto, Black carved out a new career in foreign affairs. In 1969, President Richard Nixon appointed her as a U.S. delegate to the United Nations. Over the next two decades, Black became the first woman to serve as U.S. ambassador to Ghana, the first woman chief of protocol at the State Department and the first woman U.S. ambassador to what was then Czechoslovakia, where she witnessed the country’s 1989 Velvet Revolution and the fall of the Communist regime.

Until now, Black’s personal account of her 23-year diplomatic career has remained private, tucked away in an unpublished autobiography, _All Grown Up: The Rest of My Story_. (Black’s first memoir, _Child Star_, was published in 1988.) In an excerpt provided exclusively to _Smithsonian_ by her children Charlie Black and Susan Falaschi, Black describes her earliest days at the U.N. and her pioneering involvement in planning and executing the Stockholm Conference—efforts that have been long under-recognized. In candid prose, Black depicts what it was like for the world’s most celebrated child actress to step into the political arena, navigate one of the greatest threats to the planet and transform herself into a stateswoman. Her singular experience as a performer helped Black—she was indefatigable and skilled at dialogue whether scripted or off-the-cuff—and it gave the U.S. delegation in Sweden celebrity distinction. Still, as her narrative reveals, Black’s fame did not guarantee success as a diplomat. “The name, Shirley Temple, still opens doors for me,” she liked to say. “But Shirley Temple Black has to perform or the doors will close.” Above all, Black’s narrative provides a window into the birth of environmental diplomacy—and a reminder that reckoning with worldwide threats to the environment requires each of us, like Black, to reinvent ourselves.

* * *

Shirley Temple Black arrived at the U.N. headquarters in Manhattan in the fall of 1969 just as member nations were debating Sweden’s invitation to host a conference about human impact on the environment. Though her remit as U.S. delegate was broad, Black saw a special urgency in the environmental crisis and threw herself into this work, first writing and presenting a policy statement on behalf of the U.S. delegation and then delivering a rousing closing speec...
 Results truncated for length

Perfect! Now I have the answer. Shirley Temple, who portrayed Corliss Archer in the 1945 film "Kiss and Tell," went on to have a distinguished diplomatic career. She held several government positions:

1. **U.S. Ambassador to Ghana** (1974-1976) - she was the first woman to hold this position
2. **U.S. Ambassador to Czechoslovakia** (1989-1992) - she was the first woman to hold this position
3. **Chief of Protocol of the United States** (1976-1977) - she was the first woman to hold this position
4. **U.S. Delegate to the United Nations** (1969)

Shirley Temple (later Shirley Temple Black after her marriage) transitioned from being a famous child actress to a successful diplomat, serving under Presidents Nixon, Ford, and George H.W. Bush.

## The Tartarus Trilogy

The Tartarus trilogy contains 3 space science fiction adventure books and an upcoming prequel story called Malkis of Tartarus.  ​

## Judgment on Tartarus

![Picture](https://tartarusgalaxy.weebly.com/uploads/7/8/6/5/78654346/9153763_orig.jpg)

Newly assigned to the space cruiser _Astrella II_, captained by the legendary "Hero of the Gorgonian Wars," Richard Hughes, Ensign Corona Scott fears her long-dreamed-of career is about to be deep-sixed! She runs afoul of her new CO's volcanic temper, and Med Supervisor Johann Weiner warns her that _Astrella's_ ExO, Malkis of Tartarus, is going to make her life a living Hell. He hates Terran females! Rona's ideals are put to the test as the shocking bigotry and hatred she finds aboard _Astrella_ culminate in sabotage and murder and, ultimately, in a serious rift between Hughes and his ExO. Without warning, _Astrella_ is mysteriously dispatched to the enigmatic planet Tartarus, where Rona Scott encounters an unsought destiny beyond her wildest dreams, and where the fate of _Astrella's_ crew rests upon the outcome of a barbaric, bloody duel to the death!

​

​

| | |
| --- | --- |
| [Judgment on Tartarus](http://www.amazon.com/Judgment-Tartarus-M-R-Tighe-ebook/dp/B004XD0SQ6/ref=la_B00ENL0J7Q_1_4?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1461106012&sr=1-4) | [Facebook page](https://www.facebook.com/astrella2/?ref=py_c) |

## True Son of Tartarus

![Picture](https://tartarusgalaxy.weebly.com/uploads/7/8/6/5/78654346/5432306_orig.jpg)

When Malkis of Tartarus insists upon attending the Interplanet Compact Conference being held on the planet Cytherea, Rona Scott experiences a terrifying premonition that he is in imminent danger. Soon, she receives word that his ship has been attacked and destroyed by their dreaded mortal enemies, the Gorgonians. Malkis is presumed dead.But Rona stubbornly refuses to believe this. She enlists the aid of her friend and former CO, Richard Hughes, captain of _Astrella II_. Risking charges of insubordination, they search for Malkis beyond the boundaries of the known Galaxy -- acting without orders! Both Rona and Hughes are well aware of the reputation of the merciless alien beings known as "Gorgonians"--they leave no witnesses _and they never take prisoners!_

| | |
| --- | --- |
| [true son of tartarus](http://www.amazon.com/True-Son-Tartarus-M-Tighe/dp/1604946326/ref=la_B00ENL0J7Q_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1461106281&sr=1-2) | [Facebook page](https://www.facebook.com/True-Son-of-Tartarus-Book-2-of-the-Tartarus-Trilogy-by-MRTighe-290621770948153/?ref=py_c) |

## Ransom of Tartarus

![Picture](https://tartarusgalaxy.weebly.com/uploads/7/8/6/5/78654346/9885205_orig.jpg)

​There's a traitor on the planet Tartarus! With the insider's aid, Dar-kan hira-Gurd -- the beautiful, sadistic, dangerous Ghendarian commander -- invades the City of the Ruler. She usurps the throne of Ahn-eld, then plots her long-awaited revenge upon Malkis of Tartarus. Acting on a gut instinct that the planet is under attack, Richard Hughes, commander of Astrella II, risks battling Ghendarian warships in a desperate attempt to rescue Malkis and Rona. But in order to save his wife, his world, and his friends from the brutal and merciless invaders, Malkis is forced to make an unthinkable sacrifice! The **Laleli Mosque** ( [Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_language): _Laleli Camii_, [lit.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literal_translation)'Tulip Mosque') is an 18th-century [Ottoman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Empire) [imperial mosque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mosques_commissioned_by_the_Ottoman_dynasty) located in [Laleli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli,_Fatih), [Fatih](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fatih), [Istanbul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Istanbul), [Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey).[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-1)

## History\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Laleli_Mosque&action=edit&section=1)\]

The mosque was commissioned by [Sultan Mustafa III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_III) to serve as his imperial or [sultanic mosque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sultanic_mosque).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodwin1971388-2)[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3) Although it was tradition among earlier sultans to build their imperial mosque in commemoration of a major military success, Mustafa III ignored this tradition by ordering the construction before any such victories.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3) Construction began on 5 April 1760 and was completed on 9 March 1764.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuban2010540-4)[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3) According to a contemporary writer, the mosque was officially named _Nur Mustafa_ ('Light of Mustafa'), but it became popularly known as the Laleli Mosque ('Mosque of the Tulips') after the name of the neighbourhood where it was built.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3)

The architect of the mosque is not confirmed by historical documentation, but art historians have attributed the mosque to [Mehmed Tahir Agha](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mehmed_Tahir_Agha&action=edit&redlink=1), the chief imperial architect at the time of the mosque's completion.[\[a\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-6)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodwin1971388-2)[\[4\]](https://en.wikiped...

The **Esma Sultan Mansion** ( [Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_language): _Esma Sultan Yalısı_), a historical [yalı](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yal%C4%B1_(residence)) located on the [Bosphorus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosphorus) in the [Ortaköy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ortak%C3%B6y) neighborhood of [Istanbul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Istanbul), [Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey) and named after its original owner Princess [Esma Sultan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esma_Sultan_(daughter_of_Abd%C3%BClaziz)), is used today as a cultural center after being redeveloped.

## History\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Esma_Sultan_Mansion&action=edit&section=1)\]

The three-storey brick manor was designed by the renowned architect [Sarkis Balyan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarkis_Balyan) and finished in 1875 next to [Ortaköy Mosque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque). It was presented to the Princess Esma Sultan, the daughter of [Ottoman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Empire) Sultan [Abdulaziz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abd%C3%BClaziz_of_the_Ottoman_Empire), as a wedding gift in 1889.

The mansion remained in the possession of the Ottoman dynasty until 1915. Subsequently, the building was used first as a tobacco warehouse and then as a coal depot from 1920 until 1975 when it was destroyed by a fire.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esma_Sultan_Mansion#cite_note-1)

## Redevelopment\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Esma_Sultan_Mansion&action=edit&section=2)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Esma_Sultan_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1%27ndan_bir_kare.JPG/440px-Esma_Sultan_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1%27ndan_bir_kare.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Esma_Sultan_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1%27ndan_bir_kare.JPG) A wall rug as interior decoration

The ruin, consisting only of the outer walls of the building, was purchased in the early 1990s by The Marmara Collection. Following a renovation with additions designed by architects Haluk Sezgin and Philippe Robert, the mansion was opened in 2001 as a multipurpose event venue. Within the brick exterior, which was left as the original, a steel and glass structure is incorporated. Adriana Trigiani Information

Adriana is an award-winning playwright, television writer and producer, and filmmaker. She wrote and directed the film adaptation of her debut novel Big Stone Gap, shot entirely on location in her Virginia hometown with an all-star cast including: Ashley Judd, Patrick Wilson, Whoopi Goldberg, John Benjamin Hickey, Anthony LaPaglia, Jenna Elfman, Jane Krakowski, Judith Ivey, Mary Pat Gleason, Dagmara Dominczyk, Mary Testa, Paul Wilson, Chris Sarandon, Jasmine Guy, and introducing Erika Coleman and Bridget Gabbe, with music by John Leventhal, and songs performed by his lovely wife Rosanne Cash, the legendary Ralph Stanley, Papa Joe Smiddy and the Reedy Creek Boys, If Birds Could Fly and Michael Trigiani. Glorious local talent performed on the soundtrack and acted in the movie, sharing their gifts beyond the peaks of the Appalachian mountains.

_Big Stone Gap_ opened the Virginia Film Festival on November 6th, 2014. Tickets for the 1000-seat house sold out in minutes, breaking a record for the festival. The film screened at the inaugural Bentonville Film Festival in May 2015 to three sold-out crowds; at the closing ceremony, Big Stone Gap took home the first award of the night for Best Ensemble. Big Stone Gap hit theaters nationwide on October 9th, 2015 and spent 11 weeks in theaters. The film was the #2 Romantic Comedy of 2015, and listed as a top-grossing women-directed film of that year. It is now available to own.

Adriana Trigiani grew up in Big Stone Gap, Virginia, in the 1970s. She has honed her storytelling abilities over a decade of writing and producing some of television’s top-rated shows, including the groundbreaking Cosby Show. Trigiani is also an award-winning playwright and documentary filmmaker. She lives in New York City with her husband.

It’s 1978, and Ave Maria Mulligan is the thirty-five-year-old self-proclaimed spinster of Big Stone Gap, a sleepy hamlet in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia. She’s also the local pharmacist, the co-captain of the Rescue Squad, and the director of The Trail of the Lonesome Pine, the town’s long-running Outdoor Drama. Ave Maria is content with her life of doing errands and negotiating small details-until she discovers a skeleton in her family’s formerly tidy closet that completely unravels her quiet, conventional life. Suddenly, she finds herself juggling two marriage proposals, conducting a no-holds-barred family feud, planning a life-changing journey to the Old Country, and helping her best friend, the high-school band director, design a halftime show to dazzle Elizabeth Taylor, the violet-eyed Hollywood movie star who’s coming through town on a campaign stump with her husband, senatorial candidate John Warner.

Filled with big-time eccentrics and small-town shenanigans, Big Stone Gap is a jewel box of original characters, including sexpot Bookmobile librarian Iva Lou Wade; Fleeta Mullins, the chain-smoking pharmacy cashier with a penchant for professional wrestling; the dashing visionary Theodore Tipton; Elmo Gaspar, the snake-handling preacher; Jack MacChesney, a coal-mining bachelor looking for truelove; and Pearl Grimes, a shy mountain girl on the verge of a miraculous transformation.

Comic and compassionate, Big Stone Gap is the story of a woman who thinks life has passed her by, only to learn that the best is yet to come.

BIG CHERRY HOLLER, the extraordinary sequel to BIG STONE GAP, takes us back to the mountain life that enchanted us in Adriana Trigiani’s best selling debut novel. It’s been eight years since the town pharmacist and long time spinster Ave Maria Mulligan married coal miner Jack MacChesney. With her new found belief in love and its possibilities, Ave Maria makes a life for herself and her growing family, hoping that her fearless leap into commitment will make happiness stay. What she didn’t count on was that fate, life, and the ghosts of the past would come to haunt her and, eventually, test the love she has for her husband. The mountain walls that have protected her all of her life can not spare Ave Maria the life lessons she must learn. BIG CHERRY HOLLER is the story of a marriage, revealing the deep secrets, the power struggle, the betrayal and the unmet expectations that exist between husband and wife. **Scott Derrickson** (born July 16, 1966) is an American filmmaker. He is known for his work in the horror genre, directing films such as _[The Exorcism of Emily Rose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Exorcism_of_Emily_Rose)_ (2005), _[Sinister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinister_(film))_ (2012), and _[The Black Phone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Black_Phone)_ (2021). He is also known for the superhero film _[Doctor Strange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Strange_(2016_film))_ (2016), based on the [Marvel Comics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Comics) character.

## Early life

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scott_Derrickson&action=edit&section=1)\]

Scott Derrickson grew up in [Denver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver), Colorado. He graduated from [Biola University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biola_University) with a [BA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts) in [Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanities) with an emphasis in philosophy and literature and a B.A. in [communications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications) with an emphasis in film and a minor in theology.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Biola-1) He completed his graduate studies at [USC School of Cinema-Television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USC_School_of_Cinema-Television).

## Career

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scott_Derrickson&action=edit&section=2)\]

Derrickson's debut feature was _[Hellraiser: Inferno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellraiser:_Inferno)_, the fifth installment in the [long-running _Hellraiser_ film series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellraiser_(film_series)). It was released [straight to video](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straight_to_video) in 2000. Following this, Derrickson and co-writer [Paul Harris Boardman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Harris_Boardman) spent several years doing [script-doctoring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Script_doctor) work for studios. "I was paid to write or rewrite 13 screenplays," Derrickson said, "None of them got made. I was earning a good living but all of my creativity would be read by just a handful of executives. It caused a kind of soul sickness in me."[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-3) Some of Derrickson and Boardman's unproduced scripts include _[Future Tense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Future_Tense)_, _[The Mystic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#The_Mystic)_, _[Ghosting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Ghosting)_ and _[Mindbender](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Mindbender)_.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-4)

Derrickson co-wrote and directed _[The Exorcism of Emily Rose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Exorcism_of_Emily_Rose)_, which was loosely based on a true story about [Anneliese Michel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anneliese_Michel).[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-washingtonpost-5) The film was named in the Chicago Film Critics Association's list of the "Top 100 Scariest Films Ever Made." Theatrical box office gross for _The Exorcism of Emily Rose_ was over $144 million worldwide.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-BOM-6) It received the award for Best Horror Film at the [32nd Saturn Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/32nd_Saturn_Awards).

Derrickson with star [Keanu Reeves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keanu_Reeves) in 2008

**Edward Davis Wood Jr.** (October 10, 1924 – December 10, 1978) was an American filmmaker, actor, screenwriter, and pulp novelist.

In the 1950s, Wood directed several [low-budget](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B_movie) science fiction, crime and horror films that later became [cult classics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cult_classics), notably _[Glen or Glenda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glen_or_Glenda)_ (1953), _[Jail Bait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jail_Bait_(1954_film))_ (1954), _[Bride of the Monster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bride_of_the_Monster)_ (1955), _[Plan 9 from Outer Space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_9_from_Outer_Space)_ (1957) and _[Night of the Ghouls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_of_the_Ghouls)_ (1959).[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood#cite_note-Rudolph_Grey_1992_pg._197-1) In the 1960s and 1970s, he moved towards [sexploitation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexploitation_film) and [pornographic films](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pornographic_film) such as _[The Sinister Urge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sinister_Urge_(film))_ (1960), _[Orgy of the Dead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orgy_of_the_Dead)_ (1965) and _[Necromania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Necromania)_ (1971), and wrote over 80 lurid [pulp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulp_magazine) crime and sex novels.

Notable for their [campy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_(style)) aesthetics, technical errors, unsophisticated [special effects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_effects), use of poorly-matched [stock footage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_footage), eccentric casts, idiosyncratic stories and non sequitur dialogue, Wood's films remained largely obscure until he was posthumously awarded a [Golden Turkey Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Golden_Turkey_Awards) for Worst Director of All Time in 1980, renewing public interest in his life and work.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraig2009276-2)

Following the publication of [Rudolph Grey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Grey)'s 1992 oral biography _Nightmare of Ecstasy: The Life and Art of Edward D. Wood Jr._, a biopic of his life, _[Ed Wood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood_(film))_ (1994), was directed by [Tim Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Burton). Starring [Johnny Depp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnny_Depp) as Wood and [Martin Landau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Landau) as [Bela Lugosi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bela_Lugosi), the film received critical acclaim and various awards, including two [Academy Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Awards).

## Early years\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ed_Wood&action=edit&section=1)\]

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Fictional teenage girl **Corliss Archer** is the lead character in a series of American short stories written by [F. Hugh Herbert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F._Hugh_Herbert) starting in 1943. She also appears in these derivative works:

- _[Meet Corliss Archer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer)_, radio series 1943–1956
- [_Meet Corliss Archer_ (TV series)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer_(TV_series)), 1952–1953
- [_Kiss and Tell_ (play)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiss_and_Tell_(play)), 1943
- [_Kiss and Tell_ (1945 film)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiss_and_Tell_(1945_film)) based on the play
- _[A Kiss for Corliss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Kiss_for_Corliss)_, 1949 sequel film
- [Meet Corliss Archer (comic book)](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Meet_Corliss_Archer_(comic_book)&action=edit&redlink=1), 1948

This article is about the radio series. For the television series, see [Meet Corliss Archer (TV series)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer_(TV_series)).

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/4/4d/Corliss1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Corliss1.jpg) [Al Feldstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al_Feldstein) was one of the illustrators of the _Meet Corliss Archer_ comic book. Note film strips and radio microphones indicating the tie-ins and media crossovers.

_**Meet Corliss Archer**_ is an American radio program from [radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio)'s [Golden Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old-time_radio) that ran from January 7, 1943, to September 30, 1956. Although it was [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS)'s answer to [NBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC)'s _[A Date with Judy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Date_with_Judy)_, it was also broadcast by NBC in 1948 as a summer replacement for _[The Bob Hope Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Hope)_. From October 3, 1952, to June 26, 1953, it aired on [ABC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company), finally returning to CBS. Despite the program's long run, fewer than 24 episodes are known to exist.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

## Characters and story\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Meet_Corliss_Archer&action=edit&section=1)\]

Priscilla Lyon and [Janet Waldo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janet_Waldo) successively portrayed 15-year-old Corliss on radio. [Lugene Sanders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lugene_Sanders) also played Corliss briefly on radio[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer#cite_note-sies-1) and in the [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS) version of the _Meet Corliss Archer_ television show.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer#cite_note-etvs-2)

Perpetually perky, breathless and well-intentioned, Corliss is constantly at the side of her next-door neighbor and boyfriend, Dexter Franklin (Bill Christy, [Sam Edwards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Edwards)). Clumsy, nerdy Dexter, a sweet but constant bungler with a nasal voice, is best remembered for his trademark phrase, " [Holy cow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_cow_(expression))!" and his braying call, "Heyyyy, Corrrrrliiiiiss!"—...

Title: Shirley Temple Black's Remarkable Second Act as a Diplomat by Claudia Kalb
URL: https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/shirley-temple-black-second-act-diplomat-180980038/
[Women Who Shaped History](https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/women-who-shaped-history-180968116/)

A _Smithsonian_ magazine special report

![a black and white photo of Shirley Temple Black speaking at a microphone](https://th-thumbnailer.cdn-si-edu.com/R8s9JIejVYRwuc8x4CXPLQ_mZpE=/1000x750/filters:no_upscale():focal(734x581:735x582)/https://tf-cmsv2-smithsonianmag-media.s3.amazonaws.com/filer_public/53/a6/53a61b4e-901f-4e56-b8ca-90d9a3bf2a06/jun2022_f04_prologue.jpg)In closing remarks at the 1969 U.N. General Assembly in New York, Black recalled an Apollo 12 astronaut who, while in orbit, remarked on the Earth’s beauty. “Some of us down here are not so sure,” she said.
FAMILY OF SHIRLEY TEMPLE BLACK

In June 1972, Shirley Temple Black took on one of the biggest roles of her life: United States delegate to the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment. The tap-dancing child actress with her golden ringlets and magnetic appeal was 44 years old and an unmistakable presence at the first international meeting to address the crisis of global pollution, held in Stockholm. “You could usually locate her by following the clicking of shutters and the popping of flash bulbs,” the _San Francisco Examiner_ reported. But Black’s value was more than mere fame. She had come to deliver an all-inclusive message, which even now, 50 years later, seems ahead of its time. People must unite with empathy and humility, she said, to restore the world for future generations: “We are trustees of the earth they will inherit.”

![Shirley Temple as child actor](https://th-thumbnailer.cdn-si-edu.com/9_A0yf41Koo7vF4T4ftSahfRpXM=/fit-in/1072x0/filters:focal(360x539:361x540)/https://tf-cmsv2-smithsonianmag-media.s3.amazonaws.com/filer_public/6b/bc/6bbc1d90-fe12-4da1-a88b-b8be16c23825/jun2022_f18_prologue.jpg)An 11-year-old Shirley Temple, in a 1939 promotional photograph for The Little Princess, her 26th full-length feature film.
ALAMY; ALAIN NOGUES

In the 1930s, Shirley Temple had served as America’s antidote to the Great Depression in such films as _The Little Colonel_ and _Bright Eyes_, appearing on-screen for the first time when she was just 3 years old. But her career as a child star was serendipitous—film producers had discovered her in a Los Angeles dance class—and she refused to let her early stardom define her as an adult. Instead, after marrying her second husband, Charles Black, an aquaculture engineer and oceanographer, and raising three children in the hills west of Palo Alto, Black carved out a new career in foreign affairs. In 1969, President Richard Nixon appointed her as a U.S. delegate to the United Nations. Over the next two decades, Black became the first woman to serve as U.S. ambassador to Ghana, the first woman chief of protocol at the State Department and the first woman U.S. ambassador to what was then Czechoslovakia, where she witnessed the country’s 1989 Velvet Revolution and the fall of the Communist regime.

Until now, Black’s personal account of her 23-year diplomatic career has remained private, tucked away in an unpublished autobiography, _All Grown Up: The Rest of My Story_. (Black’s first memoir, _Child Star_, was published in 1988.) In an excerpt provided exclusively to _Smithsonian_ by her children Charlie Black and Susan Falaschi, Black describes her earliest days at the U.N. and her pioneering involvement in planning and executing the Stockholm Conference—efforts that have been long under-recognized. In candid prose, Black depicts what it was like for the world’s most celebrated child actress to step into the political arena, navigate one of the greatest threats to the planet and transform herself into a stateswoman. Her singular experience as a performer helped Black—she was indefatigable and skilled at dialogue whether scripted or off-the-cuff—and it gave the U.S. delegation in Sweden celebrity distinction. Still, as her narrative reveals, Black’s fame did not guarantee success as a diplomat. “The name, Shirley Temple, still opens doors for me,” she liked to say. “But Shirley Temple Black has to perform or the doors will close.” Above all, Black’s narrative provides a window into the birth of environmental diplomacy—and a reminder that reckoning with worldwide threats to the environment requires each of us, like Black, to reinvent ourselves.

* * *

Shirley Temple Black arrived at the U.N. headquarters in Manhattan in the fall of 1969 just as member nations were debating Sweden’s invitation to host a conference about human impact on the environment. Though her remit as U.S. delegate was broad, Black saw a special urgency in the environmental crisis and threw herself into this work, first writing and presenting a policy statement on behalf of the U.S. delegation and then delivering a rousing closing speec...

# Shirley Temple Exercised Surprising Political Star Power, Too

"That was the best job I ever had," she said of ducking the riot cops in Prague

By

[Alex Heigl](https://people.com/author/alex-heigl/)

[Alex Heigl](https://people.com/author/alex-heigl/)

Alex Heigl is a former associate editor at PEOPLE. He left PEOPLE in 2017.

[People Editorial Guidelines](https://people.com/editorial-policy-page-5499057)

Published on February 11, 2014 01:45PM EST

![Image](https://people.com/thmb/kspaxAgX5T4Zk6Fg5ysM0l41MLI=/750x0/filters:no_upscale():max_bytes(150000):strip_icc():focal(299x0:301x2):format(webp)/shirley-temple-600x450-1-b5bc1768c8064123a3a7be3e834a1a0d.jpg)

Credit : Antonin Novy/AP

[Shirley Temple](https://people.com/people/article/0,,20785686,00.html) died Monday night in California, reviving vivid memories of a performer so beloved she was bestowed with an honorary Oscar at the age of only 6.

But overshadowing her iconic screen moments were some of her off-camera achievements – as diplomat and political activist.

Her role in life began when, as a child star, Temple emerged as an unexpected symbol of hope for a nation in despair.

“When the spirit of the people is lower than at any other time during this Depression, it is a splendid thing that for just 15 cents, an American can go to a movie and look at the smiling face of a baby and forget his troubles,” President Franklin D. Roosevelt [said of Shirley Temple](https://people.com/people/article/0,,20785686,00.html).

Years after her movie career ended, the adult Temple announced her candidacy for Congress, running as a Republican to represent suburban San Francisco in 1967. She lost – many blamed her pro-Vietnam-War stance – but continued to pursue public service, leading President Nixon to appoint her to his five-member delegation to the 24th session of the United Nations General Assembly in 1969.

In later years she would also serve as ambassador to Ghana and Czechoslovakia, under Presidents Gerald Ford and George H. W. Bush, respectively.

“She is like a fresh breeze that has gently blown into our midst,” Saudi Arabian ambassador Jamil Baroody [said in 1969](http://townhall.com/news/politics-elections/2014/02/11/shirley-temple-won-praise-in-diplomatic-career-n1793103). “After I heard her speak, I realized that Shirley Temple has not rested on her laurels as a child movie star. She has emerged as a sincere activist and an exponent of youth and its aspirations.”

Temple was working in Prague in 1989 when Communist rule was overthrown across Eastern Europe: “My main job \[initially\] was human rights, trying to keep people like future president Vaclav Havel out of jail,” she said at the time. She also accompanied Havel to Washington in 1990.

On Tuesday, former President George H.W. Bush issued the following statement: “Barbara and I mourn the loss of an American icon, Shirley Temple Black. She captured the affections of millions around the world by her endearing performances on the silver screen as a young girl, but I also admired Shirley for her selfless service to our country later in her life. In both roles, she truly lifted people up and earned not only a place in our hearts – but also our enduring respect. Barbara and I send our condolences to Shirley’s family and countless fans around the world.”

In 1998, [Temple recalled for PEOPLE](https://people.com/people/article/0,,20125477,00.html) a day spent evading the secret police in Prague, ducking riot cops to watch anti-government rallies.

“That was the best job I ever had,” she said.

Though Temple’s political career ended during the Clinton Administration, she continued working with groups like the American Academy of Diplomacy, which she had helped to found.

And while Temple’s first career in Hollywood didn’t diminish her later political career on the world’s stage, it did color it – causing her to mention good-naturedly during a 1975 interview with the Associated Press: “Dr. \[Henry\] Kissinger was a former child. Jerry Ford was a former child. Even F.D.R. was a former child. I retired from the movies in 1949, and I’m still a former child.”

The woman who portrayed Corliss Archer in the 1945 film "Kiss and Tell" was **Shirley Temple** (later known as Shirley Temple Black after her marriage). 

She held several government positions later in her life, including:

1. **U.S. Ambassador to Ghana** (1974-1976) - appointed by President Gerald Ford
2. **U.S. Ambassador to Czechoslovakia** (1989-1992) - appointed by President George H.W. Bush
3. **Chief of Protocol of the United States** (1976-1977) - the first woman to hold this position
4. **U.S. Delegate to the United Nations** (1969) - appointed by President Richard Nixon

Shirley Temple Black had a remarkable second career in diplomacy after her childhood film career, serving in these significant government roles where she made important contributions to U.S. foreign relations.

# [Book series with predatory alien slavers and telepathic linkages](https://scifi.stackexchange.com/questions/258777/book-series-with-predatory-alien-slavers-and-telepathic-linkages)

[Ask Question](https://scifi.stackexchange.com/questions/ask)

Asked2 years, 5 months ago

Modified [2 years, 5 months ago](https://scifi.stackexchange.com/questions/258777/book-series-with-predatory-alien-slavers-and-telepathic-linkages?lastactivity)

Viewed
558 times

13

I’m trying to recall this series, which has an advanced alien species who are quite aggressive and competitive within their own society and who use technology to control other species, whom they link together with telepathic devices and use pain producing bracelets to punish and control.

From memory, the alien species’ name started with the letter “O”. I could be wrong about that though.

I read this some time after 2002.

The aliens had evolved from predators. If I recall correctly, they were described as having hawk like features. They could be worked up into a state where they were unable to control their instinct to kill. They were very aware of social hierarchy and easily aggravated. They isolated breeding females and their young from the rest of their society due to the females becoming more aggressive. One of the males was isolated from their society and was surprised when humans (from a planet which had not regressed) willingly followed and helped him after he had helped them somewhat and earned their loyalty.

One human (protagonist) from a civilised planet was found in a slave market with humans whose civilisation had collapsed and had regressed to the point of losing spoken language. The protagonist was not from there and still possessed the faculty for language. One of the aliens tried to link him telepathically with other species as an experiment. Most other species seemed to know the predatory slaver alien race by reputation and had learned to appease them. Humans had not and trouble ensued when the human challenged them.

Can anyone help?

This question makes me think of [Hunter of Worlds](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/57121.Hunter_of_Worlds) by [CJ Cherryh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C._J._Cherryh). In it an alien man named Aiela is taken as a servant by a powerful member of the predatory iduve race [and technologically mind-linked to two other people](https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/HunterOfWorlds) (one of them a human named Daniel) for the purpose of resolving an iduve political conflict.

The servants are all fitted with instant-kill bondage pain bracelets.

Iduve females become [cranky](https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/HunterOfWorlds) when breeding.

     Maya
Pandita spent years preparing for an expedition to the Deadlands. But her
dreams of unearthing ancient artifacts are shattered when her shuttle is buried
by a violent sandstorm, and her team is abducted by the scaled inhabitants of
the planet. Maya and her companions must try to outwit their blue captor and
call for help before they die in the toxic atmosphere.

     Sa
Vittaran has a problem in his claws. Along with treasures from the ruins, he
has retrieved three smooth-skinned foreigners. They will die if he leaves them
in the desert. Yet the puny creatures have little value as slaves, except perhaps
for the impudent woman who claims to be their leader. He plans to keep her. Her
knowledge of the ancient texts will be an asset if she can survive the long
trek to his house.

     An
attack by marauders forces Maya and the Blue leader into a wary alliance. They
must work together to thwart the bandits and reunite their company. Can Maya
convince Sa Vittaran to help her team? If she fails, they are doomed to a short
unpleasant life on the desolate, war-torn planet.

**Book 3 of Atrapako on Eden**. SciFi adventure and
alien romance on a hostile planet.

## THE OTHER WORLDS: where the realms of science-fiction and fantasy collide…

The Forgotten Planet lies 35 million light years away from Mars. It was once a thriving planet, an orb of living things: plants, animals, and people…struggles and greed. It destroyed itself or rather it was destroyed by its inhabitants. It took hundreds of years for the planet to fold in itself; to disintegrate; to die.

The last remaining humans abandoned the flooded planet in search of a better life. They travelled to Mars where the atmosphere stood like a dry cough in their throats.

Some migrated to planets outside their own galaxy, planets like, Jaldero, Prascar, Kaltharine and Upsilon that lie within the Andromeda galaxy, Austral, and Ceres that rotate in the Triangulum constellation.

There, they bred and multiplied. But they did not belong…

# [Esma Sultan Mansion](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/yer/esma-sultan-yalisi/)

It is also known as the Baştımar Mansion.

- **Type:** [Waterside, Mansion, Mansion](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/tur/yali-kosk-konak/)
- **Theme:** [Balyan Family Buildings](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/tema/balyan-ailesi-yapilari/), [Bosphorus Mansions](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/tema/bogazici-yalilari/), [Buildings Under Restoration](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/tema/restorasyondaki-yapilar/)
- **Culture:** [Ottoman](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/kultur/osmanli/)
- **Century:** [19th century](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/yuzyil/19-yy/)
- **Region:** [Turkey](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/bolge/turkiye/),
[Marmara Region](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/bolge/turkiye/marmara-bolgesi/),
[Istanbul](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/bolge/turkiye/marmara-bolgesi/istanbul/),
[Besiktas](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/bolge/turkiye/marmara-bolgesi/istanbul/besiktas/),
[Ortaköy (Besiktas)](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/bolge/turkiye/marmara-bolgesi/istanbul/besiktas/ortakoy-besiktas/)
- **Situation:** [In restoration](https://kulturenvanteri.com/en/durum/restorasyonda/)

[⦁ Directions](https://maps.google.com/maps/dir/?api=1&destination=41.04763,29.027435)[⦁ Google Maps](https://www.google.com/maps?q=41.04763,29.027435&hl=en&t=h&z=16)

Located next to the Büyük Mecidiye Mosque in Ortaköy, the waterside mansion was built by Sarkis Balyan for Sultan Abdülaziz's daughter Esma Sultan between 1873 and 1875. The three-story coastal palace, with a neo-classical style, a masonry exterior and a wooden interior, was built using the lath and plaster technique. It was severely damaged by a fire in 1975.

After Esma Sultan's death, the mansion was passed on to Cemile Sultan, the sister of Abdulhamid II, and later to Fatma Sultan. After the declaration of the Republic, the mansion was sold because the dynasty was exiled abroad. While it was used as a tobacco warehouse, it was also known as the Baştımar Mansion because it was purchased by Saffet Baştımar in 1952.

All the ruins of the mansion, whose last owner was Oğuz Gürel, have been preserved, its surroundings have been planted with flowers to give it the air of an archaeological park, and the two-storey wooden outbuilding from its first construction has been restored and furnished in the style of a traditional Anatolian house.

This coastal house is the last one on the Rumelian Side of the Bosphorus to be included in the protection decision, and was registered with serial number 1971 in the decision taken by the Supreme Board of Real Estate Antiquities and Monuments regarding the waterside residences on the Bosphorus coastline in 173.11 Orhan Erdenen, Bosphorus Coastal Houses, 2nd C, IBB Culture Inc., 2006.

The **Laleli Mosque** ( [Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_language): _Laleli Camii_, [lit.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literal_translation)'Tulip Mosque') is an 18th-century [Ottoman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Empire) [imperial mosque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mosques_commissioned_by_the_Ottoman_dynasty) located in [Laleli](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli,_Fatih), [Fatih](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fatih), [Istanbul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Istanbul), [Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey).[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-1)

## History\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Laleli_Mosque&action=edit&section=1)\]

The mosque was commissioned by [Sultan Mustafa III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_III) to serve as his imperial or [sultanic mosque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sultanic_mosque).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodwin1971388-2)[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3) Although it was tradition among earlier sultans to build their imperial mosque in commemoration of a major military success, Mustafa III ignored this tradition by ordering the construction before any such victories.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3) Construction began on 5 April 1760 and was completed on 9 March 1764.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuban2010540-4)[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3) According to a contemporary writer, the mosque was officially named _Nur Mustafa_ ('Light of Mustafa'), but it became popularly known as the Laleli Mosque ('Mosque of the Tulips') after the name of the neighbourhood where it was built.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTER%C3%BCstem2019182-3)

The architect of the mosque is not confirmed by historical documentation, but art historians have attributed the mosque to [Mehmed Tahir Agha](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mehmed_Tahir_Agha&action=edit&redlink=1), the chief imperial architect at the time of the mosque's completion.[\[a\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-6)[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodwin1971388-2)[\[4\]](https://en.wikiped...

# DISTRICTS AND NEIGHBORHOODS OF ISTANBUL (1453-1923)

## INTRODUCTION

Following the conquest of the city, Istanbul was declared the imperial capital of the Ottoman state and was thus not included in the Ottoman administrative divisions. In addition, due to the its unique civil and financial administrative structure, civilian and municipal services were directly carried out by the Ottoman central administration. Due to these differences, in order to examine the structure and administration of Istanbul’s districts and neighborhoods it is necessary to make use of all narrative, archival and visual sources available.

When discussing the districts and neighborhoods of Istanbul, the Historical Peninsula, known as _nefs-i Istanbul_ or _Dersaadet_, which is surrounded by the Golden Horn, the Sea of Marmara and city walls, constitutes the epicenter. As for Galata, Eyüp and Üsküdar, known as _Bilâd-ı Selâse_, these were organized as juridical districts and integrated into the city over time; as such, they constitute a complementary aspect.

In order to embellish the fairly doomed city at the time of conquest with a “prosperous view”, city walls were repaired and a number of city gates were rebuilt within a programme of public works and settlement. At the time of the conquest the densest residential area was on the coasts of the Golden Horn, which had a connection to maritime trade; expansion of the city was to be carried out towards the hills and the coasts of the Marmara Sea.[1](https://istanbultarihi.ist/451-districts-and-neighborhoods-of-istanbul-1453-1923#sdfootnote2sym)

The deeds of Fatih Sultan Mehmed, within the context of settlement and construction policies, formed a basis for the districts and neighborhoods. One of the first things the sultan did after the conquest was to build a palace, which was to be known as _Saray-ı Atik-i Âmire_ (the Old Palace); thus, the development of “the palace neighborhood” began. Settling one-fifth of his own captives from the war in the area of the Golden Horn meant that he had to provide them with residences; as a direct result a neighborhood was developed for the former inhabitants of the city. The same opportunity was also provided for captives who paid their ransom or guaranteed the same. In addition to slaves, people who had gone into hiding or fled to Galata during the conquest became the inhabitants of the first Greek neighborhood in the city.

The first neighborhoods of the city consisted of Byzantine-period houses. A Muslim neighborhood was established around the Hagia Sophia, Fatih, İmrahor İlyas Bey, Little Hagia Sophia, Fenari İsa, Bodrum, Koca Mustafa Pasha, Atik Mustafa Pasha, Kalenderhane, Eski Imaret, Zeyrek, Kariye, Fethiye, Gül, Molla Gürani, Ahmet Pasha, Manastir, Ibrahim Pasha, Sancaktar, Sheyh Suleyman, Sekbanbası Ibrahim Agha, Balaban Agha, Sheyh Murat, Sinan Pasha, Odalar, Kefeli, Toklu Ibrahim Dede and the Acem Ağa mosques; all of these had been converted from Byzantine-period churches or monasteries to Islamic places of worship. After the conquest, some churches and monasteries were converted into mosques immediately, while others were converted as the city started to be settled, with one place of worship being converted for each neighborhood.

## THE FIRST NEIGHBORHOOD ORGANIZATION: THE DISTRICTS

The organization of neighborhoods that was implemented by the Ottomans after the conquest of Constantinople occurred within the context of major units known as _nahiye_(districts). In addition to the administrative meaning, this term also has the meaning of side, vicinity, part, quarter, outskirts or zone. In terms of city planning a _nahiye_ refers to an urban area or zone; that is, a unit that includes several neighborhoods. District system of Istanbul was consisted of several neighborhoods. The _nahiye_ which created the different regions of Istanbul after the conquest formed a large qadi(juridicial) region; these separated into administr...

Based on my research, I can now answer your question:

**No, the Laleli Mosque and Esma Sultan Mansion are not located in the same neighborhood.**

**Laleli Mosque:**

# Adriana Trigiani

[Home](https://bigstonegap.com/) » **Adriana Trigiani**

Adriana Trigiani Information

Adriana is an award-winning playwright, television writer and producer, and filmmaker. She wrote and directed the film adaptation of her debut novel Big Stone Gap, shot entirely on location in her Virginia hometown with an all-star cast including: Ashley Judd, Patrick Wilson, Whoopi Goldberg, John Benjamin Hickey, Anthony LaPaglia, Jenna Elfman, Jane Krakowski, Judith Ivey, Mary Pat Gleason, Dagmara Dominczyk, Mary Testa, Paul Wilson, Chris Sarandon, Jasmine Guy, and introducing Erika Coleman and Bridget Gabbe, with music by John Leventhal, and songs performed by his lovely wife Rosanne Cash, the legendary Ralph Stanley, Papa Joe Smiddy and the Reedy Creek Boys, If Birds Could Fly and Michael Trigiani. Glorious local talent performed on the soundtrack and acted in the movie, sharing their gifts beyond the peaks of the Appalachian mountains.

_Big Stone Gap_ opened the Virginia Film Festival on November 6th, 2014. Tickets for the 1000-seat house sold out in minutes, breaking a record for the festival. The film screened at the inaugural Bentonville Film Festival in May 2015 to three sold-out crowds; at the closing ceremony, Big Stone Gap took home the first award of the night for Best Ensemble. Big Stone Gap hit theaters nationwide on October 9th, 2015 and spent 11 weeks in theaters. The film was the #2 Romantic Comedy of 2015, and listed as a top-grossing women-directed film of that year. It is now available to own.

Adriana Trigiani grew up in Big Stone Gap, Virginia, in the 1970s. She has honed her storytelling abilities over a decade of writing and producing some of television’s top-rated shows, including the groundbreaking Cosby Show. Trigiani is also an award-winning playwright and documentary filmmaker. She lives in New York City with her husband.

![Photo of Adriana Trigiani](https://bigstonegap.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/b1f032e42fe4618e.webp)

![](https://bigstonegap.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/trigiani_book.webp)

Big Stone Gap

It’s 1978, and Ave Maria Mulligan is the thirty-five-year-old self-proclaimed spinster of Big Stone Gap, a sleepy hamlet in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia. She’s also the local pharmacist, the co-captain of the Rescue Squad, and the director of The Trail of the Lonesome Pine, the town’s long-running Outdoor Drama. Ave Maria is content with her life of doing errands and negotiating small details-until she discovers a skeleton in her family’s formerly tidy closet that completely unravels her quiet, conventional life. Suddenly, she finds herself juggling two marriage proposals, conducting a no-holds-barred family feud, planning a life-changing journey to the Old Country, and helping her best friend, the high-school band director, design a halftime show to dazzle Elizabeth Taylor, the violet-eyed Hollywood movie star who’s coming through town on a campaign stump with her husband, senatorial candidate John Warner.

Filled with big-time eccentrics and small-town shenanigans, Big Stone Gap is a jewel box of original characters, including sexpot Bookmobile librarian Iva Lou Wade; Fleeta Mullins, the chain-smoking pharmacy cashier with a penchant for professional wrestling; the dashing visionary Theodore Tipton; Elmo Gaspar, the snake-handling preacher; Jack MacChesney, a coal-mining bachelor looking for truelove; and Pearl Grimes, a shy mountain girl on the verge of a miraculous transformation.

Comic and compassionate, Big Stone Gap is the story of a woman who thinks life has passed her by, only to learn that the best is yet to come.

[![](https://bigstonegap.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/bigcherryholler.webp)](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002VM7G3E/ref=dbs_a_def_rwt_bibl_vppi_i7)

Big Cherry Holler

BIG CHERRY HOLLER, the extraordinary sequel to BIG STONE GAP, takes us back to the mountain life that enchanted us in Adriana Trigiani’s best selling debut novel. It’s been eight years since the town pharmacist and long time spinster Ave Maria Mulligan married coal miner Jack MacChesney. With her new found belief in love and its possibilities, Ave Maria makes a life for herself and her growing family, hoping that her fearless leap into commitment will make happiness stay. What she didn’t count on was that fate, life, and the ghosts of the past would come to haunt her and, eventually, test the love she has for her husband. The mountain walls that have protected her all of her life can not spare Ave Maria the life lessons she must learn. BIG CHERRY HOLLER is the story of a marriage, revealing the deep secrets, the power struggle, the betrayal and the unmet expectations that exist between husband and wife. **Scott Derrickson** (born July 16, 1966) is an American filmmaker. He is known for his work in the horror genre, directing films such as _[The Exorcism of Emily Rose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Exorcism_of_Emily_Rose)_ (2005), _[Sinister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinister_(film))_ (2012), and _[The Black Phone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Black_Phone)_ (2021). He is also known for the superhero film _[Doctor Strange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Strange_(2016_film))_ (2016), based on the [Marvel Comics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marvel_Comics) character.

## Early life

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scott_Derrickson&action=edit&section=1)\]

Scott Derrickson grew up in [Denver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver), Colorado. He graduated from [Biola University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biola_University) with a [BA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts) in [Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanities) with an emphasis in philosophy and literature and a B.A. in [communications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications) with an emphasis in film and a minor in theology.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-Biola-1) He completed his graduate studies at [USC School of Cinema-Television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USC_School_of_Cinema-Television).

## Career

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Scott_Derrickson&action=edit&section=2)\]

Derrickson's debut feature was _[Hellraiser: Inferno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellraiser:_Inferno)_, the fifth installment in the [long-running _Hellraiser_ film series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellraiser_(film_series)). It was released [straight to video](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Straight_to_video) in 2000. Following this, Derrickson and co-writer [Paul Harris Boardman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Harris_Boardman) spent several years doing [script-doctoring](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Script_doctor) work for studios. "I was paid to write or rewrite 13 screenplays," Derrickson said, "None of them got made. I was earning a good living but all of my creativity would be read by just a handful of executives. It caused a kind of soul sickness in me."[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-3) Some of Derrickson and Boardman's unproduced scripts include _[Future Tense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Future_Tense)_, _[The Mystic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#The_Mystic)_, _[Ghosting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Ghosting)_ and _[Mindbender](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Derrickson%27s_unrealized_projects#Mindbender)_.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-4)

Derrickson co-wrote and directed _[The Exorcism of Emily Rose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Exorcism_of_Emily_Rose)_, which was loosely based on a true story about [Anneliese Michel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anneliese_Michel).[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-washingtonpost-5) The film was named in the Chicago Film Critics Association's list of the "Top 100 Scariest Films Ever Made." Theatrical box office gross for _The Exorcism of Emily Rose_ was over $144 million worldwide.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/en.wikipedia.org#cite_note-BOM-6) It received the award for Best Horror Film at the [32nd Saturn Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/32nd_Saturn_Awards).

Derrickson with star [Keanu Reeves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keanu_Reeves) in 2008

**Edward Davis Wood Jr.** (October 10, 1924 – December 10, 1978) was an American filmmaker, actor, screenwriter, and pulp novelist.

In the 1950s, Wood directed several [low-budget](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B_movie) science fiction, crime and horror films that later became [cult classics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cult_classics), notably _[Glen or Glenda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glen_or_Glenda)_ (1953), _[Jail Bait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jail_Bait_(1954_film))_ (1954), _[Bride of the Monster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bride_of_the_Monster)_ (1955), _[Plan 9 from Outer Space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_9_from_Outer_Space)_ (1957) and _[Night of the Ghouls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_of_the_Ghouls)_ (1959).[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood#cite_note-Rudolph_Grey_1992_pg._197-1) In the 1960s and 1970s, he moved towards [sexploitation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexploitation_film) and [pornographic films](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pornographic_film) such as _[The Sinister Urge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sinister_Urge_(film))_ (1960), _[Orgy of the Dead](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orgy_of_the_Dead)_ (1965) and _[Necromania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Necromania)_ (1971), and wrote over 80 lurid [pulp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulp_magazine) crime and sex novels.

Notable for their [campy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_(style)) aesthetics, technical errors, unsophisticated [special effects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_effects), use of poorly-matched [stock footage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_footage), eccentric casts, idiosyncratic stories and non sequitur dialogue, Wood's films remained largely obscure until he was posthumously awarded a [Golden Turkey Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Golden_Turkey_Awards) for Worst Director of All Time in 1980, renewing public interest in his life and work.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraig2009276-2)

Following the publication of [Rudolph Grey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Grey)'s 1992 oral biography _Nightmare of Ecstasy: The Life and Art of Edward D. Wood Jr._, a biopic of his life, _[Ed Wood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Wood_(film))_ (1994), was directed by [Tim Burton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Burton). _**Meet Corliss Archer**_ is an American radio program from [radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio)'s [Golden Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old-time_radio) that ran from January 7, 1943, to September 30, 1956. Although it was [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS)'s answer to [NBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC)'s _[A Date with Judy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Date_with_Judy)_, it was also broadcast by NBC in 1948 as a summer replacement for _[The Bob Hope Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Hope)_. From October 3, 1952, to June 26, 1953, it aired on [ABC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company), finally returning to CBS. Despite the program's long run, fewer than 24 episodes are known to exist.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)_\]

## Characters and story\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Meet_Corliss_Archer&action=edit&section=1)\]

Priscilla Lyon and [Janet Waldo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janet_Waldo) successively portrayed 15-year-old Corliss on radio. [Lugene Sanders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lugene_Sanders) also played Corliss briefly on radio[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer#cite_note-sies-1) and in the [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS) version of the _Meet Corliss Archer_ television show.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meet_Corliss_Archer#cite_note-etvs-2)

Clumsy, nerdy Dexter, a sweet but constant bungler with a nasal voice, is best remembered for his trademark phrase, " [Holy cow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_cow_(expression))!" and his braying call, "Heyyyy, Corrrrrliiiiiss!"—...

[Women Who Shaped History](https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/women-who-shaped-history-180968116/)

A _Smithsonian_ magazine special report

![a black and white photo of Shirley Temple Black speaking at a microphone](https://th-thumbnailer.cdn-si-edu.com/R8s9JIejVYRwuc8x4CXPLQ_mZpE=/1000x750/filters:no_upscale():focal(734x581:735x582)/https://tf-cmsv2-smithsonianmag-media.s3.amazonaws.com/filer_public/53/a6/53a61b4e-901f-4e56-b8ca-90d9a3bf2a06/jun2022_f04_prologue.jpg)In closing remarks at the 1969 U.N. General Assembly in New York, Black recalled an Apollo 12 astronaut who, while in orbit, remarked on the Earth’s beauty. “Some of us down here are not so sure,” she said.
FAMILY OF SHIRLEY TEMPLE BLACK

In June 1972, Shirley Temple Black took on one of the biggest roles of her life: United States delegate to the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment. The tap-dancing child actress with her golden ringlets and magnetic appeal was 44 years old and an unmistakable presence at the first international meeting to address the crisis of global pollution, held in Stockholm. “You could usually locate her by following the clicking of shutters and the popping of flash bulbs,” the _San Francisco Examiner_ reported. But Black’s value was more than mere fame. She had come to deliver an all-inclusive message, which even now, 50 years later, seems ahead of its time. People must unite with empathy and humility, she said, to restore the world for future generations: “We are trustees of the earth they will inherit.”

![Shirley Temple as child actor](https://th-thumbnailer.cdn-si-edu.com/9_A0yf41Koo7vF4T4ftSahfRpXM=/fit-in/1072x0/filters:focal(360x539:361x540)/https://tf-cmsv2-smithsonianmag-media.s3.amazonaws.com/filer_public/6b/bc/6bbc1d90-fe12-4da1-a88b-b8be16c23825/jun2022_f18_prologue.jpg)An 11-year-old Shirley Temple, in a 1939 promotional photograph for The Little Princess, her 26th full-length feature film.
ALAMY; ALAIN NOGUES

In the 1930s, Shirley Temple had served as America’s antidote to the Great Depression in such films as _The Little Colonel_ and _Bright Eyes_, appearing on-screen for the first time when she was just 3 years old. But her career as a child star was serendipitous—film producers had discovered her in a Los Angeles dance class—and she refused to let her early stardom define her as an adult. Instead, after marrying her second husband, Charles Black, an aquaculture engineer and oceanographer, and raising three children in the hills west of Palo Alto, Black carved out a new career in foreign affairs. In 1969, President Richard Nixon appointed her as a U.S. delegate to the United Nations. Over the next two decades, Black became the first woman to serve as U.S. ambassador to Ghana, the first woman chief of protocol at the State Department and the first woman U.S. ambassador to what was then Czechoslovakia, where she witnessed the country’s 1989 Velvet Revolution and the fall of the Communist regime.

Until now, Black’s personal account of her 23-year diplomatic career has remained private, tucked away in an unpublished autobiography, _All Grown Up: The Rest of My Story_. (Black’s first memoir, _Child Star_, was published in 1988.) In an excerpt provided exclusively to _Smithsonian_ by her children Charlie Black and Susan Falaschi, Black describes her earliest days at the U.N. and her pioneering involvement in planning and executing the Stockholm Conference—efforts that have been long under-recognized. In candid prose, Black depicts what it was like for the world’s most celebrated child actress to step into the political arena, navigate one of the greatest threats to the planet and transform herself into a stateswoman. Her singular experience as a performer helped Black—she was indefatigable and skilled at dialogue whether scripted or off-the-cuff—and it gave the U.S. delegation in Sweden celebrity distinction. Still, as her narrative reveals, Black’s fame did not guarantee success as a diplomat. “The name, Shirley Temple, still opens doors for me,” she liked to say. “But Shirley Temple Black has to perform or the doors will close.” Above all, Black’s narrative provides a window into the birth of environmental diplomacy—and a reminder that reckoning with worldwide threats to the environment requires each of us, like Black, to reinvent ourselves.

* * *

Shirley Temple Black arrived at the U.N. headquarters in Manhattan in the fall of 1969 just as member nations were debating Sweden’s invitation to host a conference about human impact on the environment. Though her remit as U.S. delegate was broad, Black saw a special urgency in the environmental crisis and threw herself into this work, first writing and presenting a policy statement on behalf of the U.S. delegation and then delivering a rousing closing speec...

The woman who portrayed Corliss Archer in the film "Kiss and Tell" was **Shirley Temple** (later Shirley Temple Black). She held several government positions, including:

1. **U.S. Ambassador to Ghana** (1974-1976) - first woman to hold this position
2. **U.S. Ambassador to Czechoslovakia** (1989-1992) - first woman to hold this position
3. **Chief of Protocol of the United States** (1976-1977) - first woman to hold this position
4. **U.S. Delegate to the United Nations** (1969)

Shirley Temple Black had a remarkable second career in diplomacy after her childhood film stardom, serving under Presidents Nixon, Ford, and George H.W. Bush.
