[March 18, 2016](https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1571696966)

I guess this author figured out how to get more than $.99 for her book on Amazon. She split it up in 3 parts. The first one just abruptly ended and the second book starts immediately after. It wasn't really a cliff-hanger, just the start of a new chapter. Very irritating.

I thought some of the book (chapters?) was good but I just cannot believe that the heroine wouldn't be freaking out more because her alien captor couldn't even reassure that she would be bought for food or to be used sexually. I would have been a crying, freaked out mess. She does do this kind of but then makes a joke. For this alien to have done this now and have done it previously - I don't think I can make myself think anything than that he is a villain. I don't know hwo the next book can redeem him. He even sees another slave about to be sold and confirms that that species is usually eaten. I don't know why the author would have him be so cavalier about this and expect us to want to know anything about him in the future except maybe he was captured and made a cow. That would be his special karma. I'm hoping that by some miracle I change my mind about this book.

So because of the two above reasons, I'm giving this book 2 stars. We'll see how I feel about the rest of the book/series.

For the writer of science fiction, and the writer who wants to create a science fiction series, this volume teaches you how to build believable worlds, track details of your story, organize your writing, and lay out your story bible. Novice or experienced, you will pick up tricks and tips here. The Companion reveals the worldbuilding magic that makes Kayelle Allen's Tarthian Empire tick. This EPIC eBook Award winning writer shares 10k years of future history, offers peeks at scene and character creation, lays out a quick tour of the Empire, and dishes up a surfeit of secrets for fans, all in one illustrated volume. Provides organizational tips, links to marketing sites, groups supporting writers, science fiction groups, and more. Material from the author's 90+ page website is included. Original art by Jamin Allen and Kayelle Allen.

Darrow would have lived in peace, but his enemies brought him war. The Gold overlords demanded his obedience, hanged his wife, and enslaved his people. But Darrow is determined to fight back. Risking everything to transform himself and breach Gold society, Darrow has battled to survive the cutthroat rivalries that breed Society’s mightiest warriors, climbed the ranks, and waited patiently to unleash the revolution that will tear the hierarchy apart from within.

Finally, the time has come.

But devotion to honor and hunger for vengeance run deep on both sides. Darrow and his comrades-in-arms face powerful enemies without scruple or mercy. To win, Darrow will need to inspire those shackled in darkness to break their chains, unmake the world their cruel masters have built, and claim a destiny too long denied—and too glorious to surrender.

**“It certainly filled the Battlestar Galactica–shaped hole in my heart.”**— **Victoria Aveyard, bestselling author of _The Red Queen_**

**Read the _New York Times_ bestselling blockbuster that critics are calling “out-of-this-world awesome.” The first in an epic sci-fi series unlike anything else out there.**

Kady thought breaking up with Ezra was the worst thing she’d ever been through. That was before her planet was invaded. Now, with enemy fire raining down on them, Kady and Ezra are forced to fight their way onto one of the evacuating craft, with an enemy warship in hot pursuit.

But the warship could be the least of their problems. A deadly plague has broken out and is mutating, with terrifying results; the fleet’s AI, which should be protecting them, may actually be their biggest threat; and nobody in charge will say what’s really going on. As Kady plunges into a web of data hacking to get to the truth, it’s clear only one person can help her bring it all to light: Ezra.

Told through a fascinating dossier of hacked documents—including emails, schematics, military files, IMs, medical reports, interviews, and more— _Illuminae_ is the first book in a heart-stopping, high-octane trilogy about lives interrupted, the price of truth, and the courage of everyday heroes.

The **Esma Sultan Mansion** ( [Turkish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkish_language): _Esma Sultan Yalısı_), a historical [yalı](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yal%C4%B1_(residence)) located on the [Bosphorus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosphorus) in the [Ortaköy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ortak%C3%B6y) neighborhood of [Istanbul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Istanbul), [Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey) and named after its original owner Princess [Esma Sultan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esma_Sultan_(daughter_of_Abd%C3%BClaziz)), is used today as a cultural center after being redeveloped.

## History\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Esma_Sultan_Mansion&action=edit&section=1)\]

The three-storey brick manor was designed by the renowned architect [Sarkis Balyan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarkis_Balyan) and finished in 1875 next to [Ortaköy Mosque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque). It was presented to the Princess Esma Sultan, the daughter of [Ottoman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ottoman_Empire) Sultan [Abdulaziz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abd%C3%BClaziz_of_the_Ottoman_Empire), as a wedding gift in 1889.

The mansion remained in the possession of the Ottoman dynasty until 1915. Subsequently, the building was used first as a tobacco warehouse and then as a coal depot from 1920 until 1975 when it was destroyed by a fire.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esma_Sultan_Mansion#cite_note-1)

## Redevelopment\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Esma_Sultan_Mansion&action=edit&section=2)\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Esma_Sultan_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1%27ndan_bir_kare.JPG/440px-Esma_Sultan_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1%27ndan_bir_kare.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Esma_Sultan_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1%27ndan_bir_kare.JPG) A wall rug as interior decoration

The ruin, consisting only of the outer walls of the building, was purchased in the early 1990s by The Marmara Collection. Following a renovation with additions designed by architects Haluk Sezgin and Philippe Robert, the mansion was opened in 2001 as a multipurpose event venue. Within the brick exterior, which was left as the original, a steel and glass structure is incorporated. According to the GAD Architecture Group, a redesign by the architect [Gökhan Avcıoğlu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6khan_Avc%C4%B1o%C4%9Flu) was completed in 2005.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esma_Sultan_Mansion#cite_note-2) The building includes a bar, a restaurant, and an event hall at several levels.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esma_Sultan_Mansion#cite_note-3) The building is situated in a garden of 2,226 m2 (23,960 sq ft). The ground floor is 31.5 m (103 ft) wide, 27 m (89 ft) long and 3.80 m (12.5 ft) high. The first floor is merged with the second floor, having dimensions of 31.5 m (103 ft) wide, 31 m (102 ft) long and 6.80 m (22.3 ft) high.[\[4\]](https://e...

Title: Laleli: Exploring a Historic Neighborhood in Istanbul, Turkey by nomadicniko
URL: https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/laleli/
Last updated on April 25, 2025.

Laleli is a neighborhood in [Istanbul](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/), [Turkey](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/), with a few points of interest. It’s located in the [Fatih district](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/#Fatih) between [Beyazıt Square](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/beyazit-square/) and [Aksaray](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/aksaray/).

Jump To

[Toggle](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/laleli/)

## Introduction to Laleli

Laleli runs along Ordu Street (Ordu Caddesi), which is part of the historic [Divan Yolu](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/sultanahmet/#Divan_Yolu_Mese_Odos). This ancient road dates back to Roman times and led from the [Hippodrome](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/hippodrome-constantinople/) to the Golden Gate on the [Theodosian Walls](https://nomadicniko.com/turkey/istanbul/theodosian-walls-of-constantinople/). It has recently been pedestrianized.

![Laleli, Istanbul, Turkey](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201600%201060%22%20width=%221600%22%20height=%221060%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_0369.jpg%22%20data-w=%221600%22%20data-h=%221060%22%20data-bip=%22%22%3E%3C/svg%3E)Laleli

The area is popular with Russian and Eastern European tourists and is full of hotels and shops. It’s also known for its textile wholesaling businesses.

![Ordu Street](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201600%201060%22%20width=%221600%22%20height=%221060%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_1805.jpg%22%20data-w=%221600%22%20data-h=%221060%22%20data-bip=%22%22%3E%3C/svg%3E)Ordu Street

## Laleli Mosque

The [Laleli Mosque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laleli_Mosque) (Laleli Camii) is the centerpiece of the Laleli neighborhood. It was built between 1760 and 1763 by Sultan [Mustafa III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_III). The architect was Hacı Ahmed Ağa, who designed it in the Baroque style. It was completed by another architect, Mehmed Tahir Ağa. The mosque was destroyed by fire in 1783 and immediately rebuilt.

![Laleli Mosque in Laleli, Istanbul, Turkey](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201600%201313%22%20width=%221600%22%20height=%221313%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_8691.jpg%22%20data-w=%221600%22%20data-h=%221313%22%20data-bip=%22%22%3E%3C/svg%3E)Laleli Mosque![Entrance to the Laleli Mosque complex in Laleli, Istanbul, Turkey](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201382%201600%22%20width=%221382%22%20height=%221600%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_5116.jpg%22%20data-w=%221382%22%20data-h=%221600%22%20data-bip=%22%22%3E%3C/svg%3E)Entrance to the Laleli Mosque complex![Fountain and entrance to the mosque complex](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201600%201466%22%20width=%221600%22%20height=%221466%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_8677.jpg%22%20data-w=%221600%22%20data-h=%221466%22%20data-bip=%22%22%3E%3C/svg%3E)Fountain and entrance to the mosque complex![Laleli Mosque in Laleli, Istanbul, Turkey](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201600%201015%22%20width=%221600%22%20height=%221015%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_8690.jpg%22%20data-w=%221600%22%20data-h=%221015%22%20data-bip=%22%22%3E%3C/svg%3E)Laleli Mosque![Laleli Mosque in Laleli, Istanbul, Turkey](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201600%201060%22%20width=%221600%22%20height=%221060%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_8686.jpg%22%20data-w=%221600%22%20data-h=%221060%22%20data-bip=%22%22%3E%3C/svg%3E)Laleli Mosque

The mosque was named after Laleli Baba, who Sultan Mustafa III considered his guardian. It was built on a terrace above a series of shops meant to provide it with financial support. The terrace sits three to four meters higher than the street level.

![Laleli Mosque in Laleli, Istanbul, Turkey](data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns=%22http://www.w3.org/2000/svg%22%20viewBox=%220%200%201544%201435%22%20width=%221544%22%20height=%221435%22%20data-u=%22https%253A%252F%252Fnomadicniko.com%252Fwp-content%252Fuploads%252F2018%252F10%252FDSC_8676.jpg%22%20data-w=%221544%22...

Based on my search results, I can now answer your question:

**No, the Laleli Mosque and Esma Sultan Mansion are not located in the same neighborhood.**

- **Laleli Mosque** is located in the **Laleli neighborhood** in the Fatih district of Istanbul, between Beyazıt Square and Aksaray.

- **Esma Sultan Mansion** is located in the **Ortaköy neighborhood** on the Bosphorus in Istanbul.

These two landmarks are in completely different neighborhoods of Istanbul. Laleli is in the historic Fatih district on the European side, while Ortaköy is a Bosphorus-side neighborhood known for its waterfront location and the famous Ortaköy Mosque, which is near the Esma Sultan Mansion.

# WELCOME

“…If there is one thing I hope my books do always and forever, it’s that they honor working people.” _–Adriana Trigiani_

_2022 Book of the Year_ Nominee

Instant _New York Times_ Best Seller

_USA Today_ Best Seller

_Wall Street Journal_ Best Seller

_Publisher’s Weekly_ Best Seller

_Book of the Month_ Pick

_People_ Book of the Week

_Read with Jenna_ Best Beach Read of All Time

### Dear Friends,

Thank you for visiting our website! This year has been filled with exciting events and projects that we can’t wait to share with you. We love meeting you on the road and it thrills us to read your comments online. Thank you for your continued support!

New episodes of the [_You Are What You Read_](https://linktr.ee/youarewhatyoureadpodcast) podcast are released every Tuesday. Don’t miss these conversations with the luminaries of our time…Sarah Jessica Parker, Fannie Flagg, Craig Ferguson, Jacqueline Woodson, Mitch Albom, Whoopi Goldberg, Rainn Wilson, Katie Couric and so many more. Episodes are available wherever you listen to podcasts.

## 2024 Highlights

Thank you to the Lancaster Library System for hosting us with the great Kristin Hannah to discuss _The Women._ Over 2,000 readers joined us for a spectacular event to celebrate Kristin and her brilliant book. You can listen to the LIVE conversation now on [_You Are What You Read_](https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/you-are-what-you-read/id1707901821?i=1000645967212).

The Origin Project unveiled its 10th Anniversary special-edition cookbook this year at the John Fox Jr. Literary Festival at Mountain Empire Community College. [Marcelle Sussman Fischler](https://www.yahoo.com/author/marcelle-sussman-fischler/)

May 26, 2012

Link Copied

![Author Adriana Trigiani’s living room](https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/8hKWln_CkWc0tb9tbI_IPQ--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTY0MDtoPTk2MTtjZj13ZWJw/http://yre.zenfs.com/en-US/blogs/spaces/adrianalivingroom_v3.jpg)

Author Adriana Trigiani’s living room

[Adriana Trigiani](http://bit.ly/JlqYHz), the writer, TV producer and author of the bestselling novel "The Shoemaker's Wife" is known for her humorous and heartwarming tales, so richly detailed that fans join guided walking tours of the places in [Italy](http://yhoo.it/As0JK4) and Greenwich Village that she writes about.  Her own story can be told, at least in part, with a peek into her favorite room, a comfortable living room decorated in colorful raspberry and vivid Chagall blues with high ceilings and a black and gold-veined marble fireplace in the 1838 [Manhattan](http://realestate.yahoo.com/New_York/Manhattan/homes-for-sale) brownstone that she, her husband, nine-year-old daughter and a cat named Smokey call home.

_What do you like most about your living room?_

The light in the late afternoon. When the sun goes down the way the building reflects light, it turns blue. I get the fractured light.

_What does your decorating style reveal about you?_

Everything you surround yourself with in your life expresses who you are. I like comfort and color and order and books.  I come from a family of shoemakers and seamstresses. Textures, fabrics — we are really into it. I would be an interior decorator if I could.

[![Author Adriana Trigiani](https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/5FwyjfigrwYPtUmXMc52vA--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTQyMDtoPTI4MTtjZj13ZWJw/http://yre.zenfs.com/en-US/blogs/spaces/adriana_Author_Photo_2012_v2.jpg)](http://yre.zenfs.com/en-US/blogs/spaces/adriana_Author_Photo_2012_v2.jpg)

Author Adriana Trigiani

_How did you pull it all together?_

I am so beauty-on-a-budget. I don't have anything that is bought new. I refurbish it. My handy husband does a lot of it.

I got the club chairs -- from the 1930s with claw feet and square and deep -- in a resale shop. The ottoman came from a yard sale and it's redone. A friend donated the piano. The chandelier was there. I love a chandelier. It's like a drop earring in a room.

_What's your design secret?_

I collect people's rooms. I cut them out from magazines, different places, pictures I've taken. I will hunt down a fabric; I don't care how long it takes me. I am obsessive like that.  The club chairs are a [Scalamandre](http://www.scalamandre.com/) blue leopard fabric.

_Where do you hang out?_

I like to sit in a club chair. I like to be in a chair where I feel protected. I don't like chairs without sides. I do a lot of reading in there and listen to my kid play the piano. She practices every day.

_What are your favorite pieces?_

The most precious to me is my daughter's paintings. I frame them in gold and put them with the other artists. They feel like they belong in a museum that way.

_Is your design style apparent in your novels?_

Oh my god, yes. I am known for it.I wrote a novel about a decorator — "Rococo," in 2006. The settings are very important. In "The Shoemaker's Wife" they are huge. I'm very descriptive.
